citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
On 15 August 2024, two juvenile Hooded Orioles were found dead in an acclimation cage located within a large multi-
species walk-in aviary housing approximately 90 birds. This incident was self-reported to USDA Animal Care 5 days later
and the facility representative stated they have since removed the cage to prevent future fatalities. The facility
representative suspected the birds entered the cage and could not get out on their own. During inspection, a facility
representative described the cage as an approximately 4' x 4' x 6' structure on stilts the facility built out of a metal mesh
known as hardware cloth. The door to the cage is a flap of the same material which hinges from the top of the cut-out
opening and not fastened shut. The facility representative stated that the acclimation cage is rarely in use and therefore
not routinely checked during daily observations. A facility representative stated they could not determine when this
incident occurred, and the attending veterinarian did not necropsy the birds due to their desiccated condition. The facility
representative affirmed that it is not known if each individual bird housed in the walk-in aviary is observed daily.
Failure to conduct daily observations of birds does not allow for accountability of birds in the collection, potential changes
in health status or injury, which may lead to death. Daily observation of all animals must be performed to assess their
health and well-being.
Correct from this date forward of 30 August 2024.

An outdoor primary enclosure housing 16 White-winged doves has multiples areas of the cement block walls where paint
is peeling, curling or absent. Surfaces with peeling paint cannot be readily cleaned and/or sanitized. Such surfaces
present a potential hazard to animal health from microbial contamination. The facility must ensure enclosures can be
cleaned, sanitized and/or replaced when worn or soiled.
Correct by 29 October 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
On 15 August 2024, two juvenile Hooded Orioles were found dead in an acclimation cage located within a large multi-
species walk-in aviary housing approximately 90 birds. This incident was self-reported to USDA Animal Care 5 days later 
and the facility representative stated they have since removed the cage to prevent future fatalities. The facility 
representative suspected the birds entered the cage and could not get out on their own. During inspection, a facility 
representative described the cage as an approximately 4' x 4' x 6' structure on stilts the facility built out of a metal mesh 
known as hardware cloth. The door to the cage is a flap of the same material which hinges from the top of the cut-out 
opening and not fastened shut. The facility representative stated that the acclimation cage is rarely in use and therefore 
not routinely checked during daily observations. A facility representative stated they could not determine when this 
incident occurred, and the attending veterinarian did not necropsy the birds due to their desiccated condition. The facility 
representative affirmed that it is not known if each individual bird housed in the walk-in aviary is observed daily.  
 
Failure to conduct daily observations of birds does not allow for accountability of birds in the collection, potential changes 
in health status or injury, which may lead to death. Daily observation of all animals must be performed to assess their 
health and well-being. 
 
Correct from this date forward of 30 August 2024. 
3.153(a)(1)(ix) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
An outdoor primary enclosure housing 16 White-winged doves has multiples areas of the cement block walls where paint 
is peeling, curling or absent. Surfaces with peeling paint cannot be readily cleaned and/or sanitized. Such surfaces 
present a potential hazard to animal health from microbial contamination. The facility must ensure enclosures can be 
cleaned, sanitized and/or replaced when worn or soiled. 
 
Correct by 29 October 2024.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
